articles.title: Learn Yjs and Building Realtime Collaborative Apps in JavaScript
articles.description: Yjs is a CRDT (Conflict-free replicated data type) library for building collaborative and local-first apps. CDRTs are powerful but can be tricky to ‚Äòget‚Äô which is why this new interactive Yjs tutorial is so valuable. A great way to learn about building collaborative, syncing webapps from the ground up.
articles.author: Jamsocket

articles.title: Bun v1.1.44: The Fast JS Runtime Adds On-Demand Frontend Bundling
articles.description: The popular, high-performance alternative JavaScript runtime has extended its Bun.serve() HTTP handler with support for bundling frontend apps on demand using HTML imports.
articles.author: Ben Grant

articles.title: A Checklist for Your tsconfig.json
articles.description: What I love about Dr. Axel is when he‚Äôs done the hard work of figuring something out for himself, he writes it down. So it goes here, with his journey to set up a good tsconfig.json for his projects.
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: A Look at Regular Expression Pattern Modifiers
articles.description: You may be familiar with using flags to change the behavior of regexes, but Dr. Axel looks at a proposal bringing a way to change regex flags within subexpressions (e.g. /^[a-z](?-i:[a-z])$/i;). It‚Äôs at stage 4 and should land in ECMAScript 2025.
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: Accessibility Essentials Every React JS Developer Should Know
articles.description: If you‚Äôre an experienced frontend developer, these might be second nature to you by now, but this is a good roundup of the entry level ‚Äòtable stakes‚Äô for frontend accessibility, whether using React or not.
articles.author: Martijn Hols

articles.title: Five Years of React Native at Shopify
articles.description: Five years ago, Shopify said React Native was the future for mobile development at their company and they meant it, with every mobile app moving to RN over time. Here‚Äôs what they learnt along the way and why they‚Äôre sticking with it.
articles.author: Mustafa Ali (Shopify)

articles.title: Revealed: React's Experimental Animations API
articles.description: <ViewTransition /> is based on the browser's View Transition API. It‚Äôs only in pre-release versions of React, but Matt is armed with examples for you to get a feel for the potential.
articles.author: Matt Perry (Motion)

articles.title: ‚ôüÔ∏è¬†Chess.js: A Library to Manage a Chess Game
articles.description: Provides move generation, validation, piece placement, check/checkmate/stalemate detection ‚Äì "everything but the AI!" v1.0 offers a rewrite to TypeScript and a variety of enhancements.
articles.author: Jeff Hlywa

articles.title: react-nil 2.0: A React 'Null Renderer'
articles.description: An interesting experiment to use React in situations where you don‚Äôt need it to render anything, but you want to use hooks, suspense, context, and other bits of the React lifecycle. Like in, say, a Node app. Maybe this CodeSandbox example will provoke some ideas.
articles.author: Poimandres

articles.title: üîé¬†file-type 20.0: Detect the File Type of a File, Stream or Data
articles.description: For example, give it the raw data from a PNG file, and it‚Äôll tell you it‚Äôs a PNG. Uses a ‚Äòmagic number‚Äô approach so is targeted at non text-based formats. v20 adds support for yet more formats, including JARs, Word/Excel templates, and now supports ZIP decompression.
articles.author: Sindre Sorhus

articles.title: Node Web Audio API 1.0: A Web Audio API Implementation for Node
articles.description: More accurately, it‚Äôs a set of Node bindings for a Rust-powered non-browser implementation of the Web Audio API.
articles.author: IRCAM ‚Äì Centre Pompidou

articles.description: The Angular team shares a brief update on how they're working on Angular's strategy for 2025.
üëΩ Alien Signals are coming to Vue 3.6... (it's basically a really fast way to handle signals.)
Tired of seeing this everywhere in your code? Dave Rupert has a fun way to turn it into a single glyph in VS Code.
Electron 34 ‚Äì The JS, HTML and CSS desktop app framework updates to Chromium 132, Node 20.18.1, and adds a way to access the JavaScript call stack of unresponsive renderers.
Puppeteer 24 ‚Äì Popular high-level API to control Chrome or Firefox.
Cypress 14 ‚Äì Easy testing for anything that runs in a browser. Now supporting the latest versions of React, Angular, Svelte & Vite for component testing.
Storybook 8.5, ESLint 9.18.0, ESLint Config Inspector 1.0, AngularFire 19.0

articles.title: ‚úÇÔ∏è¬†CSS text-box-trim
articles.description: This handy property lets you finely control the leading space found both above and below text. Adam shows us how it works, and what problems it solves. It‚Äôs in Chrome/Edge 133 and Safari 18.2, no Firefox support just yet.
articles.author: Adam Argyle

articles.title: 'WordPress Is in Trouble'
articles.description: The continuing WordPress drama leaves a huge question mark on the overall project and the potential wide-ranging implications for the open web. There‚Äôs been a lot of chatter recently about a possible fork, but that‚Äôs already hit a Mullenweg-shaped roadblock. This story is far from over (if you want to get up to speed on things, this is a handy, detailed timeline of events).
articles.author: Gavin Anderegg

articles.title: Tight Mode: Why Browsers Produce Different Performance¬†Results
articles.description: This post offers a high-level look at what ‚ÄòTight Mode‚Äô is and how it influences the way the web works. If, like me, this was new to you, it‚Äôs a function which constrains what resources are loaded and in what order.
articles.author: Geoff Graham

articles.title: The Success of Interop 2024
articles.description: A positive look back at what this collaborative cross-browser effort achieved in the past year ‚Äî in particular the 95% interoperability reached across the key focus areas by end of 2024. Nice to see the ongoing results of working together for the benefit of the web platform at large. Interop 2025 plans are underway.
articles.author: Jen Simmons (WebKit)

articles.title: Double-Keyed Caching: How Browser Cache Partitioning Changed the Web
articles.description: In the name of privacy, browsers have now shifted from single-keyed to double-keyed caching (based around both the target URL and source origin). Here‚Äôs a good overview of the pros and cons introduced as result, with Addy explaining this complex change in detail, noting how it reduces cross-site tracking, impacts both performance and bandwidth, CDN use and more.
articles.author: Addy Osmani

articles.title: You Might Not Have a Web Performance Problem
articles.description: Some caution and caveats to consider when it comes to Lighthouse results and the performance picture they can paint.
articles.author: Matt Zeunert

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†HTML & CSS for Absolute Beginners
articles.description: Kevin‚Äôs started the year by sharing this epic 50-video course ‚Äî it explores everything from syntax, page structure, semantic HTML, CSS specificity, and much more. Assumes zero knowledge so, although entertaining and beneficial enough for us all, is perfect for a beginner ‚Äî one to pass along to those starting out.
articles.author: Kevin Powell beginner

articles.title: A Couple of CSS Tricks for HTML dialog Elements
articles.description: Namely blurring the dialog‚Äôs backdrop and disabling page scrolling when a dialog is open.
articles.author: Cassidy Williams

articles.title: Running Animations Without Keyframes
articles.description: Supported in most browsers, @starting-style provides a way to define starting values for transitions meaning no keyframes are needed.
articles.author: Temani Afif

articles.title: Easing Wizard: A CSS Easings Editor and Generator
articles.description: We‚Äôve shared tools like this before, but this one might be the best-designed one yet. You can copy the code as CSS or Tailwind and there‚Äôs an option to deep link to the current easing config settings.
articles.author: Matthias Martin

articles.title: Open Props UI
articles.description: A CSS UI library exploring how next-gen HTML & CSS features can change the way we create components. Version 1.0 hit yesterday, adding a ton of components. Repo here.
articles.author: Felix B

articles.title: Comic Mono
articles.description: A legible monospace font (see image above) based on that very typeface we‚Äôve all been trained to recognize since childhood. Available in a regular and bold weight. Is your editor ready for this..?
articles.author: Thai Pangsakulyanont

articles.title: ARIA DevTools: A Chrome Extension to Easily Spot Missing ARIA Labels and Roles
articles.description: Provides a visualization of a website‚Äôs accessibility tree, so you can see where you might need to add ARIA-based landmarks.
articles.author: Mateusz Zieli≈Ñski

articles.title: Photo Gradient: An Online Tool to Generate & Customize Mesh Gradients From Any Image
articles.description: The download is in PNG format and you can also just randomly generate and edit mesh gradients without uploading an image.
articles.author: Daniel Destefanis

articles.title: tailwind-to-inline: Transform Tailwind Classes to Inline Styles
articles.description: This is an npm script you can run on your Tailwind-based templates should you want to convert them to inline styles, such as for use in HTML emails.
articles.author: Vardan Hakobyan
